elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane (TPOM) with deprotonated 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (H2bdc) or 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (5-OH-H2bdc) in the presence of nitrates of cadmium, zinc, and cobalt in H2O or H2O/DMF produced five new complexes, namely, {[Cd2(TPOM)(bdc)2]·(H2O)5(DMF)} n (1), {[Zn2(TPOM)(bdc)2]·(H2O)4} n (2), {[Zn2(TPOM)(bdc)2]·(H2O)} n (3), {[Co2(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)2(H2O)2]·(H2O)5} n (4), and {[Cd2(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)2]·(H2O)2} n (5). These complexes were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, and X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Complex 1 reveals a 2-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional (3D) framework with pcu topology constructed from binuclear Cd clusters and TPOM ligands. In addition, the experiment of single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) structural transformations upon guest exchange was tested. Zn complexes 2 and 3 possess different 3D frameworks and are prepared from TPOM and H2bdc under different reaction conditions. In complexes 4 and 5, TPOM and 5-OH-H2bdc link Co or Cd centers to generate 3D interpenetrating frameworks with bbf and qtz topology. In addition, thermal stabilities and photochemical properties of these new complexes in the solid state have been studied.

elements.content: Over the past decade, there has been much interest in the fabrication of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their novel architectures and potential applications in photochemical areas, molecular magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and molecular sorption. Many factors, such as the different organic ligands, solvent systems, metal ions, and counterions, are found to greatly influence the structures, which makes it difficult to predict the construction of molecular architectures. elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decade, there has been much interest in the fabrication of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their novel architectures and potential applications in photochemical areas, molecular magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and molecular sorption. Many factors, such as the different organic ligands, solvent systems, metal ions, and counterions, are found to greatly influence the structures, which makes it difficult to predict the construction of molecular architectures. Therefore, systematic studies of diversified conditions leading to different structures in the formation of coordination polymers are important and of intense interest.

elements.content: Recently, a large number of mixed-ligands MOFs have been reported, most of which use N-containing ligands in metal-polycarboxylate systems. It is known that combining different ligands in a complex offers greater tunability of structural frameworks than using single ligands, and the use of mixed-ligands is a good choice for the construction of new polymeric structures. In particular, coordination polymers with flexible ligands exhibit more complex and unusual structures, as functional groups on the ligands offer variable configurations. Flexible pyridyl ligands, such as 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)-ethane (bpe), 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)-ethylene (dpe), and 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)-propane (bpp), often freely rotate to meet the requirement of coordination geometries of metal ions in the assembly of their MOFs. Recently, various coordination polymers with different structures and functions have been reported. Ryan’s group reported that reactions of different copper salts with flexible ligand tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane (TPOM) give various novel coordination polymers with the structure aberrancy. Various metal clusters assembled with the TPOM linker also have been reported lately. To the best of our knowledge, there have been only two mixed-ligand polymers containing TPOM and d-camphoric acid. No other mixed-ligand polymers containing TPOM have been reported. To test the use of mix-ligands to give new architectures and topologies, we selected TPOM, H2bdc, and 5-OH-H2bdc as ligands (Scheme ) and different divalent metal salts, and solvothermally synthesized five new coordination polymers {[Cd2(TPOM)(bdc)2]·(H2O)5(DMF)} n (1), {[Zn2(TPOM)(bdc)2]·(H2O)4} n (2), {[Zn2(TPOM)(bdc)2]·(H2O)} n (3), {[Co2(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)2(H2O)2]·(H2O)5} n (4), and {[Cd2(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)2]·(H2O)2} n (5). The new compounds are characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and X-ray crystallography. Crystal structures, topological analyses, and thermal properties of the compounds are presented. In addition, the photochemical properties for complexes 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are discussed in detail.

elements.content: Reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received. Ligand TPOM was prepared by the literature methods. IR absorption spectra of the complexes were recorded in the range of 400−4000 cm−1 on a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets (5 mg of sample in 500 mg of KBr). C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu−Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The photoluminescence lifetime were measured with an Edinburgh Instruments FLS920P fluorescence spectrometer. Solid-state UV−vis diffuse reflectance spectra was performed at room temperature using Shimadzu UV-3600 double monochromator spectrophotometer, and BaSO4 was used as a 100% reflectance standard for all materials. Luminescent spectra were recorded with a SHIMAZU VF-320 X-ray fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. The as-synthesized samples were characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on a Perkin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer Pyris 1 TGA up to 1023 K using a heating rate of 10 K min−1 under N2 atmosphere.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

Reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received. Ligand TPOM was prepared by the literature methods. IR absorption spectra of the complexes were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets (5 mg of sample in 500 mg of KBr). C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The photoluminescence lifetime were measured with an Edinburgh Instruments FLS920P fluorescence spectrometer. Solid-state UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra was performed at room temperature using Shimadzu UV-3600 double monochromator spectrophotometer, and BaSO4 was used as a 100% reflectance standard for all materials. Luminescent spectra were recorded with a SHIMAZU VF-320 X-ray fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. The as-synthesized samples were characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on a Perkin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer Pyris 1 TGA up to 1023 K using a heating rate of 10 K min-1 under N2 atmosphere.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (30.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2bdc (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and TPOM (22.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in 9 mL of DMF/H2O (2:1, v/v). The final mixture was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) under autogenous pressure and heated at 90 °C for 2 days. Large quantities of colorless-block crystals were obtained, and crystals were filtered off, washed with mother liquid, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield of the reaction was ca. 76% based on TPOM. Anal. Calcd for C44H48O18N5Cd2: C, 45.57%, H, 4.17%, N, 6.04%; found C, 45.52%, H, 4.15%, N, 6.11%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3442(s), 3072(s), 2938(m), 2503(m), 1672(s), 1605(s), 1504(s), 1462(s), 1434(s), 1382(s), 1285(s), 1212(s), 1091(w), 1059(s), 1031(s), 892(w), 833(s), 752(s), 659(m), 519(m).

elements.content: Single crystals of 1−5 were prepared by the methods described in the synthetic procedures. X-ray crystallographic data of 1−5 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted on glass fiber. All measurements were made on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures of complexes 1−5 were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structure and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using a full-matrix least-squares procedure based on F 2 values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The distribution of peaks in the channels of 1 and 4 was chemically featureless to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve these issues, the contribution of the electron density by the remaining water molecule was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The numbers of solvent water molecules in 1 and 4 were obtained by element analyses. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , while the selected bond lengths and angles are given in the (Table S1).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals of 1-5 were prepared by the methods described in the synthetic procedures. X-ray crystallographic data of 1-5 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted on glass fiber. All measurements were made on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures of complexes 1-5 were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structure and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using a full-matrix least-squares procedure based on F 2 values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The distribution of peaks in the channels of 1 and 4 was chemically featureless to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve these issues, the contribution of the electron density by the remaining water molecule was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The numbers of solvent water molecules in 1 and 4 were obtained by element analyses. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , while the selected bond lengths and angles are given in the  (Table S1).

R 1 = Σ||F o| − |F c||/|Σ|F o|. wR 2 = {Σ[w(F o 2 − F c 2)2]/Σ[w(F o 2)2]}1/2, where w = 1/[σ 2 (F o 2 ) + (aP)2 + bP], P = (F o 2 + 2F c 2)/3.

Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals compound 1 crystallized in the orthorhombic crystal system of Ibca. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains an independent Cd(II) cation, one bdc2− anion, half TPOM ligand, two and half free disordered lattice water molecules, and half a DMF molecule. As shown in Figure a, the bdc2− ligand adopts two coordination modes. One carboxylate group adopts a bismonodentate coordination mode to bridge two Cd centers, whereas another carboxylate group coordinates to the same Cd center by adopting a chelating coordination mode. In 1, the Cd(II) atoms were bridged by carboxylate ligands to form an binuclear cluster with Cd···Cd separation of 3.962(3) Å. The Cd(II) center is six-coordinated to form distorted octahedral geometry by four O (O1, O2, O11#4, O12#3) atoms from H2bdc ligands in the equatorial position. These O atoms are almost in a plane and the Cd−O lengths are in the range of 2.297(2)−2.525(3) Å, and two N (N3, N1#5) atoms from TPOM are in the axial position. The Cd−N lengths are 2.303(3) and 2.309(3) Å, which are similar to those found in other Cd(II) complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of {[Cd2(TPOM)(bdc)2]⋅(H2O)5(DMF)} n  (1)

Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals compound 1 crystallized in the orthorhombic crystal system of Ibca. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains an independent Cd(II) cation, one bdc2- anion, half TPOM ligand, two and half free disordered lattice water molecules, and half a DMF molecule. As shown in Figure a, the bdc2- ligand adopts two coordination modes. One carboxylate group adopts a bismonodentate coordination mode to bridge two Cd centers, whereas another carboxylate group coordinates to the same Cd center by adopting a chelating coordination mode. In 1, the Cd(II) atoms were bridged by carboxylate ligands to form an binuclear cluster with Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separation of 3.962(3) Å. The Cd(II) center is six-coordinated to form distorted octahedral geometry by four O (O1, O2, O11#4, O12#3) atoms from H2bdc ligands in the equatorial position. These O atoms are almost in a plane and the Cd-O lengths are in the range of 2.297(2)-2.525(3) Å, and two N (N3, N1#5) atoms from TPOM are in the axial position. The Cd-N lengths are 2.303(3) and 2.309(3) Å, which are similar to those found in other Cd(II) complexes.

elements.content: According to the studies by Ryan et al., the distortion of TPOM can be assessed by comparing the N···Ccore···N angles defined by the central carbon atom of the pentaerythrityl core (Ccore) and the nitrogen atoms of the pyridyl groups, as well as the torsion angle of Ccore−CH2−O−Cpyridyl. In 1, the flexible ligand TPOM adopts a conformation that holds four pyridyl groups in a highly distorted tetrahedral orientation, and two pairs of pyridyl groups are almost in parallel. The angles of N···Ccore···N are 2 × 155.914(4)°, 2 × 154.326(4)°, 35.800(4)° and 35.179(3)°, showing that the ligand deviates significantly from tetrahedral geometry. The -CH2O- spacers that connect each pyridyl group to the core adopt orientations that are not fully extended, with Ccore−CH2−O−C torsion angles of 130.553(3)° and 130.971(3)°.

In 1, the flexible ligand TPOM adopts a conformation that holds four pyridyl groups in a highly distorted tetrahedral orientation, and two pairs of pyridyl groups are almost in parallel. The angles of N⋅⋅⋅Ccore⋅⋅⋅N are 2 × 155.914(4)°, 2 × 154.326(4)°, 35.800(4)° and 35.179(3)°, showing that the ligand deviates significantly from tetrahedral geometry. The -CH2O- spacers that connect each pyridyl group to the core adopt orientations that are not fully extended, with Ccore-CH2-O-C torsion angles of 130.553(3)° and 130.971(3)°.

elements.content: Each binuclear Cd cluster coordinates to four bdc2− anions to form a 2D layered network (Figure b); the size of this net is 8.847 × 18.124 Å2. The TPOM ligands linking binuclear Cd clusters in the axial position of the coordination octahedron further generate an infinite 3D framework (to see the framework clearly, “X” represents the TPOM ligand) containing channels along the a, b, c axis (Figure c). The sizes for channels are about 12.375 × 16.517 Å2, 12.375 × 4.191 Å2, and 8.847 × 18.124 Å2, and these channels are filled by lattice water and DMF molecules. A better insight into the nature of this intricate framework can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node and connection nets. The binuclear Cd cluster can be regarded as 6-connected nodes with all crystallographical independent TPOM ligands and bdc2− acting as 2-connected nodes. Therefore, the whole structure can thus be represented as a pcu alpha-Po network topology (with the Schläfli symbol {412·63}) (Figure d). The potential voids are large enough to be filled via mutual interpenetration of an independent equivalent framework, generating a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure e). Even with this interpenetration, the framework is still open, containing some 3D channels. Calculation with PLATON shows that the effective volume for the inclusion is 35% of the crystal volume.

elements.content: Thermal analysis showed that compound 1 lost lattice DMF and H2O molecules before 200 °C, and the framework collapsed at 350 °C. We were thus interested to see whether compound 1 exhibited reversible single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) structural transformations upon guest exchange. To study this property, the crystals were washed and suspended in methanol (MeOH) overnight, and then washed with dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) several times. The resultant solids were then dried at 100 °C under a vacuum overnight to obtain 1a. The unit cell of 1a can be indexed to give a orthorhombic cell of a′ = 14.16(1) Å, b′ = 21.03(0) Å, c′ = 32.43(1) Å. It is noted that the peak of 1a slightly broadens in the b direction from 20.90 to 21.03 Å, while that in the a direction shrinks from 14.57 to 14.16 Å. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies indicated that 1a slightly deviates from the pristine compound 1. On the other hand, when any of these materials is kept in DMF for 3 days, 1b is obtained, which is very similar to pristine compound 1, as confirmed by the coincidence of the peak positions and relative intensities in the PXRD pattern ().

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of C2/c. The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) cation, half TPOM molecule, one bdc2− anion, and two disordered lattice water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each Zn1(II) is four-coordinate with distorted tetrahedral geometry, composed of two carboxylic O(O3, O5) atoms from two bdc2− anions and two N (N2, N1#1) atoms from a TPOM ligand. The Zn−O lengths are in the range of 1.924(4)−1.962(4) Å and the Zn−N lengths are 2.002(4)−2.044(5) Å. They are both within the ranges reported for tetrahedral Zn complexes.

Crystal Structure of {[Zn2(TPOM)(bdc)2]⋅(H2O)4} n  (2)

Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of C2/c. The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) cation, half TPOM molecule, one bdc2- anion, and two disordered lattice water molecules. As shown in Figure a, each Zn1(II) is four-coordinate with distorted tetrahedral geometry, composed of two carboxylic O(O3, O5) atoms from two bdc2- anions and two N (N2, N1#1) atoms from a TPOM ligand. The Zn-O lengths are in the range of 1.924(4)-1.962(4) Å and the Zn-N lengths are 2.002(4)-2.044(5) Å. They are both within the ranges reported for tetrahedral Zn complexes.

elements.content: The conformation of TPOM in 2 is substantially different from that in 1. The N···Ccore···N angles are in the range of 72.302(5)−150.732(6)°, showing the TPOM ligand in 2 deviates from tetrahedral geometry. The -CH2O- spacers that connect each pyridyl group to the core adopt conformations that are nearly fully extended, with Ccore−CH2−O−C torsion angles of 177.746(4)° and 169.917(4)°. Each Zn atom coordinates to two TPOM ligands to form an infinitely 2D network (Figure b). These 2D networks form a 3D framework via sharing the Zn cations with the bdc2− anion (Figure c). To reduce multidimensional structures to simple node and connection nets, the Zn ions and all crystallographically independent TPOM ligands can be regarded as 4-connected nodes and the bdc2− ligands as 2-connected nodes. By analysis, compound 2 has a (62·84) topology (Figure d).

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3 were prepared from the same reactants but have different structures due to the different reaction conditions and solvents. The crystal structure of 3 was solved in the space group P2(1)/c. As depicted in Figure a, there are two types of coordination environments around the zinc(II) ions. Two Zn(II) ions have a similar distorted tetrahedral geometry with two carboxylic O atoms from two bdc2− anions and two N atoms from two TPOM ligands. The lengths of Zn−O (Zn−N) and the angles of O−Zn−O (N−Zn−N) are very close. The Zn−O lengths are 1.901(3)−1.922(3) Å and the Zn−N lengths are 1.986(3)−2.034(3) Å. Similarly, the angles of O−Zn−O are 104.45(1)−119.37(1)° and N−Zn−N are 108.61(1)°−109.69(1)°.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Zn2(TPOM)(bdc)2]⋅(H2O)} n  (3)

Compounds 2 and 3 were prepared from the same reactants but have different structures due to the different reaction conditions and solvents. The crystal structure of 3 was solved in the space group P2(1)/c. As depicted in Figure a, there are two types of coordination environments around the zinc(II) ions. Two Zn(II) ions have a similar distorted tetrahedral geometry with two carboxylic O atoms from two bdc2- anions and two N atoms from two TPOM ligands. The lengths of Zn-O (Zn-N) and the angles of O-Zn-O (N-Zn-N) are very close. The Zn-O lengths are 1.901(3)-1.922(3) Å and the Zn-N lengths are 1.986(3)-2.034(3) Å. Similarly, the angles of O-Zn-O are 104.45(1)-119.37(1)° and N-Zn-N are 108.61(1)°-109.69(1)°.

elements.content: In compound 3, the TPOM ligand adopts a conformation unlike those observed in complexes 1 and 2. The −CH2−O spacers adopt orientations that are no fully extended, and the Ccore−CH2−O−C torsion angles vary from 106.802(4)° to 176.718(3)°. As a result, the TPOM ligand adopts a highly irregular conformation in which the N···Ccore···N angles vary from 81.788(6)° to 126.457(7)°. The neighboring Zn(II) ions are connected by the TPOM ligands to form an infinite 2D network containing [Zn2((TPOM0.5)2)] n loops (Figure b). The bdc2− anions link the 2D network to form a 3D framework (Figure c). (“X” is used to represent the TPOM ligand to see the framework more clearly.). By topology analysis, compound 3 has a ({4·5·62·72}{4·52·6·7·8}{52·62·72}) topology. In compound 3, the distances of Zn···Zn linked by H2bdc and TPOM ligands are 9.763 and 10.612 Å. Respectively, the large distances between the metal atoms result in large cavities within the network, and thus two identical frameworks fill this space to generate a 3-fold interpenetrating network (Figure d).

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system, space group P2/c. As shown in Figure a, there are two types of coordination environments around the Co(II) ions. Co1 is in an octahedral coordination sphere, which is defined by two carboxylic oxygen atoms from two different bdc2− anions, two coordinated water O atoms at the equatorial position, and the other two coordinated N atoms from TPOM at the axial positions. Co2 is four-coordinated and resides in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment defined by two oxygen atoms from two different bdc2− anions and two nitrogen atoms from two TPOM ligands. The average bond lengths of Co−O and Co−N are 2.053(3) and 2.105(3) Å, respectively. These distances fall in the normal range found in other Co complexes. In the environment around the Co1, the angles of N1−Co1−N1#1, O2−Co1−O2#1, and O6−Co−O6#1 are almost 180°, while in the environment around the Co2, the angle of N2−Co2−N2#2 is 90.958(2)° and the angle of O3#3−Co2−O3#4 is 120.694(1)°.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Co2(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)2(H2O)2]⋅(H2O)5} n  (4)

Compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system, space group P2/c. As shown in Figure a, there are two types of coordination environments around the Co(II) ions. Co1 is in an octahedral coordination sphere, which is defined by two carboxylic oxygen atoms from two different bdc2- anions, two coordinated water O atoms at the equatorial position, and the other two coordinated N atoms from TPOM at the axial positions. Co2 is four-coordinated and resides in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment defined by two oxygen atoms from two different bdc2- anions and two nitrogen atoms from two TPOM ligands. The average bond lengths of Co-O and Co-N are 2.053(3) and 2.105(3) Å, respectively. These distances fall in the normal range found in other Co complexes. In the environment around the Co1, the angles of N1-Co1-N1#1, O2-Co1-O2#1, and O6-Co-O6#1 are almost 180°, while in the environment around the Co2, the angle of N2-Co2-N2#2 is 90.958(2)° and the angle of O3#3-Co2-O3#4 is 120.694(1)°.

elements.content: In compound 4, the TPOM ligand adopts a comformation holding the four pyridyl groups in an irregular orientation, the N···Ccore···N angles range from 71.508(5) to 122.904(5)°. The -CH2O- spacers that connect each pyridylphenyl group to the core adopt a conformation that is substantially extended with Ccore−CH2−O−C torsion angles of 165.585(4)° and 174.208(3)°. Each octahedral and tetrahedral Co atom coordinates to TPOM ligands to form infinitely wave-like 2D network along the b axis (Figure b). The 5-OH-bdc2− anions link two Co atoms belonging to different 2D network through the carboxylate coordination to form a 3D framework (Figure c). From the b axis, these reticulate channels were filled with 5-OH-bdc2− (Figure d).

The -CH2O- spacers that connect each pyridylphenyl group to the core adopt a conformation that is substantially extended with Ccore-CH2-O-C torsion angles of 165.585(4)° and 174.208(3)°. Each octahedral and tetrahedral Co atom coordinates to TPOM ligands to form infinitely wave-like 2D network along the b axis (Figure b). The 5-OH-bdc2- anions link two Co atoms belonging to different 2D network through the carboxylate coordination to form a 3D framework (Figure c). From the b axis, these reticulate channels were filled with 5-OH-bdc2- (Figure d).

elements.content: A better insight into the nature of this intricate framework is provided by a topology analysis. The Co(II) center and TPOM ligands can be regarded as 4-connected nodes with the 5-OH-bdc2− anions acting as 2-connected note. The whole structure is thus represented as a bbf network topology (with the Schläfli symbol {64·82}{66}2). In order to minimize the presence of large cavities and to stabilize the framework during the assembly process, other identical networks are filled in the cavities giving a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure e).

elements.content: Crystallographic analysis reveals that 5 crystallized in the orthorhombic crystal system of P21212. An interesting feature in this network is that a 1D helical channel exists. Because 5 is a chiral crystal system, there is a pair of enantiomers of opposite helical channels (compounds 5L and 5R), so we select 12 crystals to measure and find that the proportion of 5L and 5R is about one to three; the reason is probably that the two kinds of crystals have different solubilities. Here, only the compound of right-handed helical structure (5R) is discussed in detail. The 5L is illustrated in (Chart S1). As illustrated in Figure a, Cd1 adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry that is formed by four O atoms from two 5-OH-bdc2− anions [Cd1−O: 2.253(5)−2.437(5) Å] and two N atoms from two different TPOM ligands [Cd1−N: 2.278(5)−2.282(5) Å]. The conformation of the TPOM ligand is closely analogous to the one adopted in compound 2. That conformation holds the four pyridyl groups in an irregular orientation in which the N···Ccore···N angles are 119.259(7)−125.438(7)°. The -CH2O- spacers adopt orientations that are nearly fully extended in which the Ccore−CH2−O−C torsion angles are 169.456(5)° and 178.300(5)°.

Crystal Structure of {[Cd2(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)2]⋅(H2O)2} n  (5)

Crystallographic analysis reveals that 5 crystallized in the orthorhombic crystal system of P21212. An interesting feature in this network is that a 1D helical channel exists. Because 5 is a chiral crystal system, there is a pair of enantiomers of opposite helical channels (compounds 5L and 5R), so we select 12 crystals to measure and find that the proportion of 5L and 5R is about one to three; the reason is probably that the two kinds of crystals have different solubilities. Here, only the compound of right-handed helical structure (5R) is discussed in detail. The 5L is illustrated in  (Chart S1). As illustrated in Figure a, Cd1 adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry that is formed by four O atoms from two 5-OH-bdc2- anions [Cd1-O: 2.253(5)-2.437(5) Å] and two N atoms from two different TPOM ligands [Cd1-N: 2.278(5)-2.282(5) Å]. The conformation of the TPOM ligand is closely analogous to the one adopted in compound 2. That conformation holds the four pyridyl groups in an irregular orientation in which the N⋅⋅⋅Ccore⋅⋅⋅N angles are 119.259(7)-125.438(7)°. The -CH2O- spacers adopt orientations that are nearly fully extended in which the Ccore-CH2-O-C torsion angles are 169.456(5)° and 178.300(5)°.

elements.content: The TPOM ligands linked Cd(II) ions to form an infinitely wave-like 2D sheet along the c axis (Figure b). An interesting feature in this compound is that a 1D right-handed helical channel (Figure c) exists. The 5-OH-bdc2− anions link two Cd atoms belonging to different 2D networks through the carboxylate coordination to form a 3D framework (Figure d,e). A topology analysis reveals that the structure can be represented as a qtz network topology (with the Schläfli symbol {64·82}). The potential voids are large enough to be filled via mutual interpenetration of an independent equivalent framework, generating a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure f).
elements.clean_text: The TPOM ligands linked Cd(II) ions to form an infinitely wave-like 2D sheet along the c axis (Figure b). An interesting feature in this compound is that a 1D right-handed helical channel (Figure c) exists. The 5-OH-bdc2- anions link two Cd atoms belonging to different 2D networks through the carboxylate coordination to form a 3D framework (Figure d,e). A topology analysis reveals that the structure can be represented as a qtz network topology (with the Schläfli symbol {64⋅82}). The potential voids are large enough to be filled via mutual interpenetration of an independent equivalent framework, generating a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure f).

elements.content: The luminescent properties of free ligands TPOM, H2bdc, and 5-OH-H2bdc as well as complexes 1, 2, 3, and 5 in the solid state at room temperature were studied, as depicted in the (Figure S2). Intense emissions of the free H2bdc and 5-OH-H2bdc ligands were observed with wavelengths from 350 to 410 nm (λmax = 390 and 365 nm). The curve of free TPOM ligand showed an weak emission with a wavelength from 420 to 475 nm (λmax = 450 nm). Complexes 1, 2, 3, and 5 exhibit their emission characters similar to that of the free H2bdc and 5-OH-H2bdc ligands. The emission peaks at 420 nm (λex = 340 nm) in 1, 430 nm (λex = 350 nm) in 2, 435 nm (λex = 338 nm) in 3, and 433 nm (λex = 340 nm) in 5 show a small red shift compared with that of the H2bdc and 5-OH-H2bdc ligands, which is probably due to enhanced conjugation in the ligands upon metal coordination. The stronger emission band in 3 is mainly due to the 3-fold interpenetration of the architecture, which causes a compact stack of various atoms, enhancing the “rigidity” of the ligand and thus reducing the loss of energy through a radiationless pathway. In addition, the UV−vis absorption spectrum of compound 4 was carried out in the crystalline state at room temperature (TPOM and 5-OH-H2bdc in solid state). As shown in , TPOM and 5-OH-H2bdc show intense absorption peaks at 220−260 nm and 280−330 nm, which can be ascribed to π−π* transitions of the ligands. Energy bands of complex 4 from 520 to 590 nm are assigned as d−d transitions, while lower energy bands from 340 to 370 nm are assigned as metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) transitions. The bands at 520 to 590 nm are broad probably because compound 4 contains two types of Co(II) environments (tetrahedral and octahedral) and their spectroscopic properties are very close. Furthermore, the emission decay lifetimes of compounds 1, 2, 3, and 5 were monitored and the curves are best fitted by biexponentials in solid. The emission decay lifetimes of the compounds 1, 2, 3, and 5 are complex 1, τ1 = 2.88 μs (19.85%) and τ2 = 16.66 μs (80.15%) (χ2 = 1.387, ), complex 2, τ1 = 2.13 μs (28.68%) and τ2 = 16.50 μs (71.32%) (χ2 = 1.287, ), complex 3, τ1 = 2.67 μs (17.07%) and τ2 = 16.71 μs (82.93%) (χ2 = 1.398, ), complex 5, τ1 = 2.79 μs (21.91%) and τ2 = 16.73 μs (78.09%) (χ2 = 1.287, ).

elements.content: To estimate the stability of the coordination architectures, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). For complex 1, the weight loss of 13.96% observed from 20 to 247 °C corresponds to the departure of the lattice water and DMF (calcd 13.93%), and the structure was then decomposed starting at 350 °C. For 1a, a rapid weight loss of 9.71% observed from 20 to 75 °C corresponds to the loss of lattice water molecules, which is probably because the solvent-losing compound 1 is inclined to absorb water molecules from the air. For 1b, a rapid weight loss of 3.43% from 20 to 60 °C corresponding to the loss of lattice water molecules, while the second weight loss of 8.29% from 60 to 250 °C is attributed to the loss of DMF molecules. The structures 1a and 1b were all decomposed starting at 350 °C. The TGA curve of 2 is less stable with a 6.59% (calcd 6.52%) weight loss of four lattice water molecules from 20 to 140 °C, and the framework collapsed at 340 °C. In complex 3, a small weight loss of 1.83% (calcd 1.95%) was observed from 20 to 180 °C due to the release of one lattice water molecule. The structure was then decomposed starting at 350 °C. Complex 4 lost two coordinated and five lattice water molecules (12.09%; calcd 12.25%) before 170 °C, and the framework begins to decompose at 390 °C. Complex 5 lost two lattice water molecules at 20−110 °C with a weight loss of 3.39% (calcd 3.34%), and the network subsequently collapsed at 405 °C. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1−5. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in (Figures S1, S9−S12). They show that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis and PXRD Results

To estimate the stability of the coordination architectures, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). For complex 1, the weight loss of 13.96% observed from 20 to 247 °C corresponds to the departure of the lattice water and DMF (calcd 13.93%), and the structure was then decomposed starting at 350 °C. For 1a, a rapid weight loss of 9.71% observed from 20 to 75 °C corresponds to the loss of lattice water molecules, which is probably because the solvent-losing compound 1 is inclined to absorb water molecules from the air. For 1b, a rapid weight loss of 3.43% from 20 to 60 °C corresponding to the loss of lattice water molecules, while the second weight loss of 8.29% from 60 to 250 °C is attributed to the loss of DMF molecules. The structures 1a and 1b were all decomposed starting at 350 °C. The TGA curve of 2 is less stable with a 6.59% (calcd 6.52%) weight loss of four lattice water molecules from 20 to 140 °C, and the framework collapsed at 340 °C. In complex 3, a small weight loss of 1.83% (calcd 1.95%) was observed from 20 to 180 °C due to the release of one lattice water molecule. The structure was then decomposed starting at 350 °C. Complex 4 lost two coordinated and five lattice water molecules (12.09%; calcd 12.25%) before 170 °C, and the framework begins to decompose at 390 °C. Complex 5 lost two lattice water molecules at 20-110 °C with a weight loss of 3.39% (calcd 3.34%), and the network subsequently collapsed at 405 °C. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1-5. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in  (Figures S1, S9-S12). They show that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized five new complexes by the self-assembly of TPOM, H2bdc, and 5-OH-H2bdc ligands and Cd(II), Zn(II), and Co(II) ions under solvothermal conditions. The results show that adjusting the configuration of flexible ligands is a good approach to achieve diversity in MOF structures. For the TPOM ligand, the flexible nature of the spacer allows the ligand to bend and rotate to change the N···Ccore···N angles and Ccore−CH2−O−C torsion angles. The rigid polycarboxylate acids also play an important role. These ligands tend to construct the coordination polymers exhibiting high porosity, and the potential void allows a number of individual nets to interpenetrate with each other. Subsequent works will be focused on the structures and properties of a series of coordination complexes constructed by the TPOM ligand with more auxiliary polycarboxylate acids ligands and metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized five new complexes by the self-assembly of TPOM, H2bdc, and 5-OH-H2bdc ligands and Cd(II), Zn(II), and Co(II) ions under solvothermal conditions. The results show that adjusting the configuration of flexible ligands is a good approach to achieve diversity in MOF structures. For the TPOM ligand, the flexible nature of the spacer allows the ligand to bend and rotate to change the N⋅⋅⋅Ccore⋅⋅⋅N angles and Ccore-CH2-O-C torsion angles. The rigid polycarboxylate acids also play an important role. These ligands tend to construct the coordination polymers exhibiting high porosity, and the potential void allows a number of individual nets to interpenetrate with each other. Subsequent works will be focused on the structures and properties of a series of coordination complexes constructed by the TPOM ligand with more auxiliary polycarboxylate acids ligands and metal ions.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (30.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2bdc (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and TPOM (22.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in 9 mL of DMF/H2O (2:1, v/v). The final mixture was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) under autogenous pressure and heated at 90 °C for 2 days. Large quantities of colorless-block crystals were obtained, and crystals were filtered off, washed with mother liquid, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield of the reaction was ca. 76% based on TPOM. Anal. Calcd for C44H48O18N5Cd2: C, 45.57%, H, 4.17%, N, 6.04%; found C, 45.52%, H, 4.15%, N, 6.11%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3442(s), 3072(s), 2938(m), 2503(m), 1672(s), 1605(s), 1504(s), 1462(s), 1434(s), 1382(s), 1285(s), 1212(s), 1091(w), 1059(s), 1031(s), 892(w), 833(s), 752(s), 659(m), 519(m).

Synthesis of {[Zn<sub>2</sub>(TPOM)(bdc)<sub>2</sub>]·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2bdc (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and TPOM (22.2 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 9 mL of DMF/H2O (2:1, v/v). The final mixture was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) under autogenous pressure and heated at 90 °C for 2 days. A large quantity of colorless-plank crystals were obtained, washed with mother liquid, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield of the reaction was ca. 65% based on TPOM. Anal. Calcd for C41H40O16N4Zn2: C, 50.48%, H 4.13%, N, 5.74%; found C, 44.58%, H, 4.07%, N 5.81%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3422(w), 1614(s), 1510(s), 1442(m), 1363(s), 1296(s), 1212(s), 1147(w), 1090(w), 1060(m), 1031(s), 886(w), 828(s), 749(s), 536(m).

Synthesis of {[Zn<sub>2</sub>(TPOM)(bdc)<sub>2</sub>]·(H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2bdc (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and TPOM (22.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in 6 mL of distilled water and 3 mL of CH3OH. The pH was adjusted to 7.0 by addition of 1 M NaOH solution. The final mixture was sealed in a 15-mL Parr Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessel and heated at 140 °C for 3 days, and then the reaction system was cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 3 were obtained, washed with water, and dried under ambient conditions. (Yield: 53% based on TPOM). Anal. Calcd for C41H34O13N4Zn2: C, 53.44%, H, 3.72%, N, 6.08%; found C, 53.48%, H, 3.74%, N 5.96%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3421(w), 1612(s), 1567(m), 1508(m), 1441(w), 1357(s), 1294(s), 1208(s), 1141(w), 1059(w), 1031(s), 831(w), 751(m), 533(m).

Synthesis of {[Co<sub>2</sub>(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>5</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5-OH-H2bdc (18.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), and TPOM (22.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 9 mL of DMF and H2O (1:2, v/v). The final mixture was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 2 days. Purple crystals were obtained (Yield: 66% based on TPOM). Anal. Calcd for C41H46O21N4Co2: C, 46.96%, H, 4.42%, N, 5.34%; found C, 46.82%, H, 4.49%, N, 5.32%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3462(w), 2359(w), 1663(s), 1612(s), 1570(s), 1436(m), 1385(s), 1333(s), 1298(s), 1211(s), 1104(w), 1060(s), 1039(m), 971(w), 898(s), 880(s), 829(s), 783(s), 718(s), 666(m), 570(m), 540(s).

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)<sub>2</sub>]·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (30.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5-OH-H2bdc (18.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), and TPOM (22.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 12 mL of DMF and H2O (1:3). The final mixture was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) under autogenous pressure and heated at 95 °C for 3 days. Colorless-block crystals were obtained. Yield of the reaction was ca. 71% based on TPOM. Anal. Calcd for C41H36O16N4Cd2: C, 46.21%, H, 3.41%, N, 5.26%; found C, 46.17%, H, 3.45%, N, 5.29%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3405(w), 2510(w), 1667(s), 1609(s), 1570(s), 1554(s), 1508(s), 1469(m), 1382(s), 1295(s), 1210(s), 1098(w), 1031(s), 976(w), 937(w), 878(m), 849(s), 830(w), 781(s), 739(s), 538(s).

Intense emissions of the free H2bdc and 5-OH-H2bdc ligands were observed with wavelengths from 350 to 410 nm (λmax = 390 and 365 nm). The curve of free TPOM ligand showed an weak emission with a wavelength from 420 to 475 nm (λmax = 450 nm). Complexes 1, 2, 3, and 5 exhibit their emission characters similar to that of the free H2bdc and 5-OH-H2bdc ligands. The emission peaks at 420 nm (λex = 340 nm) in 1, 430 nm (λex = 350 nm) in 2, 435 nm (λex = 338 nm) in 3, and 433 nm (λex = 340 nm) in 5 show a small red shift compared with that of the H2bdc and 5-OH-H2bdc ligands, which is probably due to enhanced conjugation in the ligands upon metal coordination. The stronger emission band in 3 is mainly due to the 3-fold interpenetration of the architecture, which causes a compact stack of various atoms, enhancing the “rigidity” of the ligand and thus reducing the loss of energy through a radiationless pathway. In addition, the UV−vis absorption spectrum of compound 4 was carried out in the crystalline state at room temperature (TPOM and 5-OH-H2bdc in solid state). As shown in , TPOM and 5-OH-H2bdc show intense absorption peaks at 220−260 nm and 280−330 nm, which can be ascribed to π−π* transitions of the ligands. Energy bands of complex 4 from 520 to 590 nm are assigned as d−d transitions, while lower energy bands from 340 to 370 nm are assigned as metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) transitions. The bands at 520 to 590 nm are broad probably because compound 4 contains two types of Co(II) environments (tetrahedral and octahedral) and their spectroscopic properties are very close. Furthermore, the emission decay lifetimes of compounds 1, 2, 3, and 5 were monitored and the curves are best fitted by biexponentials in solid. The emission decay lifetimes of the compounds 1, 2, 3, and 5 are complex 1, τ1 = 2.88 μs (19.85%) and τ2 = 16.66 μs (80.15%) (χ2 = 1.387, ), complex 2, τ1 = 2.13 μs (28.68%) and τ2 = 16.50 μs (71.32%) (χ2 = 1.287, ), complex 3, τ1 = 2.67 μs (17.07%) and τ2 = 16.71 μs (82.93%) (χ2 = 1.398, ), complex 5, τ1 = 2.79 μs (21.91%) and τ2 = 16.73 μs (78.09%) (χ2 = 1.287, ).

Thermal Analysis and PXRD Results

To estimate the stability of the coordination architectures, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). For complex 1, the weight loss of 13.96% observed from 20 to 247 °C corresponds to the departure of the lattice water and DMF (calcd 13.93%), and the structure was then decomposed starting at 350 °C. For 1a, a rapid weight loss of 9.71% observed from 20 to 75 °C corresponds to the loss of lattice water molecules, which is probably because the solvent-losing compound 1 is inclined to absorb water molecules from the air. For 1b, a rapid weight loss of 3.43% from 20 to 60 °C corresponding to the loss of lattice water molecules, while the second weight loss of 8.29% from 60 to 250 °C is attributed to the loss of DMF molecules. The structures 1a and 1b were all decomposed starting at 350 °C. The TGA curve of 2 is less stable with a 6.59% (calcd 6.52%) weight loss of four lattice water molecules from 20 to 140 °C, and the framework collapsed at 340 °C. In complex 3, a small weight loss of 1.83% (calcd 1.95%) was observed from 20 to 180 °C due to the release of one lattice water molecule. The structure was then decomposed starting at 350 °C. Complex 4 lost two coordinated and five lattice water molecules (12.09%; calcd 12.25%) before 170 °C, and the framework begins to decompose at 390 °C. Complex 5 lost two lattice water molecules at 20−110 °C with a weight loss of 3.39% (calcd 3.34%), and the network subsequently collapsed at 405 °C. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1−5. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in (Figures S1, S9−S12). They show that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.

metadata.title: Syntheses, Structures, and Photoluminescence of Five New Metal−Organic Frameworks Based on Flexible Tetrapyridines and Aromatic Polycarboxylate Acids
